Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “How was your day? Did you eat? Tell me everything!” I smiled, knowing she’d worry if I didn’t reply soon. Every evening, I made it a point to call or text my parents, sharing little stories and answering their questions. It was our way of staying close, even though I lived away from home now. But tonight, my mind kept drifting to the article my mentor had sent earlier. “No rush, just thought you’d find it interesting,” she’d said, but I knew she expected me to read it and maybe even bring it up in our next meeting. I wanted to impress her, to show I was committed and thoughtful. As I typed a reply to Mom, my eyes flicked to the unread article. I felt torn—if I spent time catching up with my parents, I’d be too tired to focus on the reading. But if I dove into the article now, I’d break our daily routine and disappoint them. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I sat there, phone in hand, heart pounding, unsure which part of myself to let down tonight.
